item.title: Analyse your fitness tracks in R
item.description:
Analyze your running tracks with R

This tutorial shows you how to analyse your running data that are stored nowadays by many tracking apps. Most of these apps allow you to export the tracks and your training progress. I´ve been using runtastic lately which allows you to export the stored data (unfortunately only!) once a week and the export took three days to be available. Not very customer friendly but thats another story to be told…..

The data used in this tutorial can be downloaded under this link and is a .gpx file that was exported from my fitness app. I was jogging up a small mountain called Holzer Alm. It is in the backyard of my home place at Tegernsee and I regularly go there for jogging.

The first thing that we do is to load the needed packages and read in the data in R:

library(plotKML)
library(magrittr)
library(ggplot2)
library(geodist)
library(ggmap)

#####read in the gpx
r <-   plotKML::readGPX(" ...\\\thedata.gpx", metadata = TRUE, bounds = TRUE, waypoints = TRUE, tracks = TRUE, routes = TRUE)

As the .gpx file reads as a list into R, we need to extract the dataframe containing the single waypoints of the logged track from this list. We do this by accessing the deeper levels of the list.

t<-r[4][[1]][[1]][[1]]
head(t)

#gives us this result
       lon      lat               ele                     time
1 11.71829 47.73594  737.620361328125 2020-04-05T16:09:41.000Z
2 11.71823 47.73600 737.6251220703125 2020-04-05T16:09:45.000Z
3 11.71812 47.73605 737.7398071289062 2020-04-05T16:09:47.000Z
4 11.71806 47.73607 737.8793334960938 2020-04-05T16:09:49.000Z
5 11.71803 47.73604 738.0138549804688 2020-04-05T16:09:51.000Z
6 11.71803 47.73599 738.2489013671875 2020-04-05T16:09:53.000Z

By doing this we extract a dataframe that contains all the single waypoints of our recorded track. The dataframe holds information to the geographic coordinates, the elevation and the recording time of each waypoint. We can now already inspect the track.

#have a first look at the track
plot(rev(t$lon), rev(t$lat), type = "l", col = "tomato", lwd = 3, bty = "n", ylab = "Latitude", xlab = "Longitude")

We want to analyse our performance during the run, including the speed and distance. To get this information we calculate the distance and the speed between each waypoint. For this, we use simple loops. The geographic distance between each waypoint and the previous one can be calculated by the geodist package. The command automatically takes the lat and lon coordinates in our dataframe as an input.

#caluculate the distance of every waypoint to the previous waypoint
t$dist.prev<- rep(NA,2772)

for (i in seq(1:nrow(t)-1)){
t$dist.prev[i] <-  geodist(t,)[i,i+1]
}

Our velocity is defined as the rate of change of position with respect to time. So we need to calculate the time passed between the recording of each waypoint and later divide the distance by the time passed.

# transformation of the time column, so that R can interpret it
t$time <- strptime(t$time, format = "%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%OS")

#calculate the differences in time of each waypointto the previous one
#we use abs() command to have absolute values, as the differences 
#would become negative numbers without it
t$time.diff<- rep(NA,2772)
for (i in seq(1:nrow(t)-1)){
  t$time.diff[i] <-  abs(as.numeric(difftime(t$time[i], t$time[i+1])))
}

#there are some errors in the time measurements where the app
#recorded the same time for two points.
#This would result infinite values for velocity
# so we will get rid of this
t$time.diff[t$time.diff == 0]<-1

Now with elapsed time and distance we can calculate speed, smooth it a little and inspect the data. To plot the distance on the x-axis we also calculate the cumulative distance of each waypoint. The black line is the raw velocity between each waypoint. It is very fuzzy and we can reduce the noise in the data by applying the loess smoothing shown by the blue line.

t$speed.m.per.sec <- t$dist.prev / t$time.diff
t$speed.km.per.h  <- t$speed.m.per.sec * 3.6 # transofrm to kmh^-1
t$speed.km.per.h[is.na(t$speed.km.per.h)] <-0#last entry converted from NA to 0

####smooth everything a little using lowess 
t$loess.speed <- lowess(t$speed.km.per.h, f = 0.1)$y

#cumulative distance
t$cum.dist<-cumsum(t$dist.prev)

Now with all the data generated, we can plot the track, colorize it according to the velocity and add a basemap to it. This is done using the ggmap package. We use the outer bounds of our waypoint coordinates as the corners of the map and add a little offset to make it look even nicer.

#get the basemap
basemap<- get_map(c(left = min(lon)-0.01, bottom = min(lat)-0.005, 
                    right = max(lon)+0.01, top = max(lat)+0.005),
                    source="osm", zoom=14)

#and plot the map
ggmap(basemap) 
               + geom_point(data = t, 
                 aes(lon,lat,col = loess.speed), size=2, stroke = 0, alpha=0.7) 
               + labs(x = "Longitude", y = "Latitude",
                      title="Run up Holzer Alm", col="Speed [km/h]") 
               + scale_colour_gradient(high = "red",
                                       low = "green",)

This time we use a free basemap from OpenStreetMap. There are plenty of other options for basemaps such as googleMaps. Feel free to play around with the settings a little.

What a very nice visualization!

item.title: Fieldwork @ Ödenwinkelkees 2019
item.description:
The best part of working as an ecologist definitely is fieldwork. Summer 2019 was an amazing three months full of botanizing, arthropod collecting and microbiome sampling. The aim of the project is to better understand the inital processes shaping the development of biodiversity. Along the receding ice fronts of alpine glaciers new ecosystems start to emerge on the sand and soil left behind the glacier snout. For our project, we chose the forefield of the Ödenwinkel glacier as our model system. The Ödenwinkelkees is located at 2100m a.s.l. in the Hohe Tauern National Park, Austria.

As the 2018-19 winter was a record-breaking in terms of snow, most of the surroundings were still covered in snow when we first arrived at the fieldsite by the mid of June.

Nevertheless, by mid of September we managed to have all our tasks completed. Here I would like to share some impressions of the practical part of field work:

​

​

​

And of course there was enough time left to enjoy the marvellous nature around. Some impressions of the botanical part of field work:

item.title: Autumn in Italy
item.description:
When temperatures are falling and the first frosts end the vegetation period in the northern Alps, there is still a lot to discover in the Italian part of the mountain range. The mild-climate, a result of the influence of the Mediterranean Sea, invites for hikes until late in the season and allows nature lovers to make some interesting findings.

Only after a few meters we could already spot the caterpillar of a swallowtail feeding on an umbelliferous plant. Probably this little fellow will not evolve into an imago this year but will instead hibernate as a pupa and serve as the progenitor of next years swallowtail populations.

Our track lead us through the sundrenched southern slope of Monte Pizzocolo. Even though it was already late in the year, we had to start early as the south-exposed trail still becomes a very unpleasant place during the mid-day´s heat. The reflection on the water surface on the one and the heated up rocks on the other side make this part of the trail a furnace, especially during the summer months.

The summit welcomes visitors with the pleasure of an amazing view on the lake and the surrounding mountains. The horizon even stretches to the glaciated peaks of the Central Alps in the backgorund. Right below the summit there is a small chapel and a small bivouac site, the Bivacco due Aceri. As the name indicates, it is located between two maple trees and invites hikers to rest and even stay over night.

Up at the top we could spot a pink that was still in blossom and brought a glimpse of summer to us. We chose to descend on quite a steep trail that lead along the northern slope of the mountain. On the way back, we passed through a marvelous deciduous forest mainly consisting of sycamore maple and beech trees.

These forests host populations of my favorite plant, the European Cyclamen. During my undergraduate studies, I was working at the botanical garden in Augsburg. One of my jobs was to clean out the Cyclamen that were propagated there. These overbred flowers in the garden are very sensitive to mold, such as Botrytis, that infects the densely grown flower stalks and the bottom side of the leaves. During the main growing season in late summer and early autumn it was a Sisyphean challenge to keep up with removing old leaves and stalks.

item.title: Bryophyte Recording East Styria 2019
item.description:
Bryophyte Recording in East Styria 2019

Organized by the BLAM (Bryological and Lichenological Association for Central Europe) and the Natural History Museum Johanneum of Graz about twenty Bryologists from all German-speaking countries in Europe met in East Stryria. For four days the bryophyte-rich surroundings of the small town Miesenbach have been visited.

In total we found 404 Bryophyte species in only three days! Among them some interesting records as Tetrodontium ovatum, Ulota coarctata, Cyrtomnium hymenophylloides, Kiaeria blytii and many more…
